docs.lead_paragraph: On the final night of the 1998 session, the State Legislature passed a measure requiring that the names of H.I.V.-positive people be reported to the state and mandating that government health workers ask infected people to name their sexual partners so they can be notified that they are at risk. The bill passed the Democrat-led Assembly 112 to 34, shortly before 2 this morning. The Republican-controlled Senate passed it Thursday night by a vote of 55 to 6. A large majority of Assembly members were known to favor the measure, which had been kept from a vote by the leadership in recent years. Aides to Gov. George E. Pataki, said he intends to sign it.

headline.main: Albany Passes Bill Requiring H.I.V. Tracking

docs.abstract: New York State Legislature, on final night of 1998 session, passes measure requiring that names of HIV-positive people be reported to state and mandating that govt health workers ask infected people to name their sexual partners so that they can be notified that they are at risk; aides to Gov Pataki says he intends to sign it; in addition to HIV tracking measure, both houses of Legislature pass two bills resulting from 11th-hour agreements with Pataki, one to create appeals process for people whose health insurance companies deny coverage for treatment, and another to expand health care for poor children (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL A3-16 Albright Seeks to Improve U.S. Relations With Iran Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright invited Iranians to join with the United States in drawing up ''a road map leading to normal relations.'' Ms. Albright said it was time to find ways to bridge the gap between the two nations. A1

docs.lead_paragraph: Delegates to the American Medical Association voted today to retain their current leadership, rejecting a presidential candidate who was critical of a failed deal to allow the commercial use of the A.M.A.'s name. The 484 delegates of nation's largest organization of physicians elected as their president Dr. Thomas R. Reardon, a 64-year-old general practitioner from Portland, Ore., who was the A.M.A. chairman at time of the contract, with the Sunbeam Corporation. Dr. Reardon is to begin his one-year term in June 1999.

headline.main: A.M.A. Retains Chief Despite Sunbeam Furor

docs.abstract: American Medical Association convention, Chicago, votes to retain current leadership, electing as president Dr Thomas R Reardon, who was chairman when AMA agreed to allow commercial use of its name by Sunbeam Corp; he defeats Dr Raymond Scalettar, who campaigned against leadership's handling of failed deal; delegates also approve all-out effort to let consumers choose their health insurance from competing plans (S)
docs.snippet: Delegates to the American Medical Association voted today to retain their current leadership, rejecting a presidential candidate who was critical of a failed deal to allow the commercial use of the A.M.A.'s name.    The 484 delegates of nation's...

docs.lead_paragraph: The Senate today jettisoned broad legislation meant to discourage teen-agers from smoking, the most ambitious and contentious measure before Congress, and left almost no hope that it could be revived this year. The bill, which had been debated on the Senate floor for a month, was set aside when supporters, mostly Democrats, could not win the 60 votes needed to clear two procedural hurdles.

headline.main: SENATE DROPS TOBACCO BILL WITH '98 REVIVAL UNLIKELY; CLINTON LASHES OUT AT G.O.P.

docs.abstract: Senate sets aside broad bill meant to discourage teen-agers from smoking; supporters, mostly Democrats, fail to win 60 votes needed to cut off debate and bar bill's return to committee; Democrats vow to bring issue up at every opportunity, but concede there is little chance of success this year; Republican opponents of bill argue it was primarily tax bill to pay for Government programs; Sen John McCain, maverick Republican who sponsored bill, stresses importance of preventing teen-age addiction to smoking; Pres Clinton, citing threat to children, scores Senate; blames tobacco companies and their advertising drive; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: In a sobering blow to the many doctors who want to recapture control of their patients' care, the California Medical Association is shutting down the managed care company that it and 7,500 of its member physicians created to take on the state's big health maintenance organizations. After two and a half frustrating years, three chief executives and $11 million in losses, the association's managed care company, California Advantage, will file for bankruptcy today, said Steven Fleisher, a lawyer for the association. The business will be slowly liquidated while the company's insurer fulfills the terms of its existing contracts for patient care, some extending until next May.
docs.abstract: California Medical Association is closing California Advantage, managed care company it formed with 7,500 of its members to compete with state's big health maintenance organizations; company, which lost $11 million over 2 1/2 years, will file for bankruptcy and be slowly liquidated, while fulfilling terms of existing patient care contracts (M)
